raw_text:
Murphy: That was a bruising battle
 
 That's what I call a tough game. It was very physical and fair play to the Italians they made us work very hard for our victory.
 
 Their organisation was very, very good and they proved again that they are getting better and better as the years go by. It is by far the strongest Italian team that we have faced. We knew all along that we would be a huge threat particularly the first game in the Championship. It was not like the days gone by when you could get scores on the board early. We had to work our socks off and try and build our scores gradually. It was really hard work out there and the players have plenty of bumps and bruises to prove it. I'm not too bad, but there are one or two others who will be feeling it a bit on Monday morning. In the backs, we were not frustrated at such, but the new rucking laws were a little bit problematical. The different interpretations between the referee and the players was a little difficult. But we managed to get the ball in our hands and I got a try near the end of the first half. It's always good to score. It was great work by Brian and I always knew I had scored even though it went upstairs to the video referee. Eddie (O'Sullivan) was very calm at half-time even though we were only 8-6 ahead. He spelled out what we needed to do and advocated getting the ball out of our own territory.
 
 That new ruck law made it a bit more difficult to get out of our own half. We were penalised a lot at the breakdown, and if they had kicked all their chances at goal we would have been behind at the break. So really we went back to playing a territory game and simplifying things and having more patience on the ball. Every one was a little down after the game following the injuries to Brian and Gordon. As yet we do not know the full extent of the injuries, but it does not that good. Now we have to focus on Scotland and only six days to recover. It's a big ask after such a bruising encounter. I was very impressed the way the Scots played against the French on Saturday. It could so easily have gone their way but for a couple of decisions. We will be under no illusions it is going to be tough for us. In the meantime, when in Rome ... .
llama3.2:1b: Murphy discusses the physicality and competitiveness of Italy's team during the Championship match.
The game was intense with fair play and strong organisation from both sides.
Despite being a tough opponent, the English team managed to score one try near the end of the first half.
The new rucking laws were problematic, causing penalties at breakdowns.
The team adapted by playing a territory game and simplifying their attack, taking more patience on the ball.
Following the injuries to key players like Brian and Gordon, the England team must focus on Scotland in six days' time.
They are aware that the match will be challenging but not underestimating Italy's strength.
llama3.2:3b: We were outmuscled by Italy in a tough game that was very physical and fair.
The Italians' organisation was strong and we had to work hard to build our scores gradually.
We scored a try near the end of the first half but struggled with the new rucking laws, which made it difficult to get out of our own territory.
Several players are injured, including Brian and Gordon, and now we must focus on Scotland in six days for what promises to be another tough test.
gemma2:2b: Murphy describes the match as "bruising," acknowledging Italy's strong organization and the hard-fought victory.
They faced difficulties adjusting to new ruck laws but managed to gain control and secure a try before halftime.
Injuries hampered the team, and they need time for recovery before facing Scotland.
Despite being impressed by Scotland's performance against France, Murphy anticipates a tough match against them due to their strong team play and favorable outcome in certain situations.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Murphy describes an Italian team's hard-fought victory over Scotland and the changes this had on Brian O'Malley's performance.
The team was described as "very good" but acknowledged it could have gone their way against France earlier.
The player noted that they were more focused and composed during games, especially after injuries to Brian and Gordon.
Injuries in Scotland are expected, and Murphy suggests the Scots might face tougher challenges if they come up short in this competition.
qwen2.5:1.5b:
The summary of the text can be expressed as follows:

**Summary:**
Murphy led a challenging match against an excellent Italian team, emphasizing their superior organization and physicality despite being behind early.
The new rucking laws caused some difficulties but were overcome through adaptability and strategy.
After Brian's injury, players focused on preparing for Scotland and recovering from the hard-fought game against France.
qwen2.5:3b: Murphy describes a physically demanding match with Italy where fair play was evident despite physicality.
The team acknowledged their strong organization and improvement over time.
Despite initial frustration with new rucking laws, they managed well until halftime.
They outscored Italy 8-6 after simplifying tactics and playing more patiently.
Head coach Eddie O'Sullivan praised the team's resilience post-game recoveries.
Murphy expressed concern about injuries but noted it was crucial to focus on upcoming match against Scotland in six days.
opencoder:1.5b:
Murphy: That was a tough game

That's what I call a frustrating battle.
It wasn't easy playing for our victory as we had been struggling hard for it.
They showed great organisation and they proved again that they are getting better with each season.
It is the strongest team that we have faced ever.
We knew all along that we would face this same match up coming the Championship.
However, every day was different.
We had to work our socks off trying and building our scores gradually.
It was not only hard work out there but also the players were having a bit of trouble with their marks.
I don't think I am bad, but there are few who will feel it a bit on Monday morning.
In the back, we didn't face this situation so well.
The different interpretations between the referee and the players were complicated by the fact that they had to take into account the ruck laws.
The new rule made it more difficult to get out of the game.
We got penalized because of the breakdown, but if they had kicked all their chances at goal, we would have been behind.
It was also very hard work as we were getting bored after these injuries.
Brian and Gordon played very well and provided clear strategies to recover from this situation.
It's always good to score.
The way Brian and I scored even though it went upstairs to the video referee helped us in the end.
Even though Eddie was calm, he insisted on spending more time learning what was needed to do.
As for the future, we will definitely have to focus on Scotland as we are not sure how long it will take to recover.
When in Rome ... .
They played very well against France, and it took two decisions for a couple of days.
It's always good to score and that is one way to get over this situation.

The Italian team demonstrated exceptional strength, proving themselves to be increasingly better over the years.
They faced a formidable challenge in their first game of the championship, requiring hard work and patience to build scores.
Players were physically drained due to bruised players, but the team remained determined.
During the game, Brian and I scored, earning a shout for my contribution despite the score moving up during video review.
The new rucking laws posed challenges, particularly in setting boundaries, with players sometimes getting penalized at the breakdown.
However, the team adjusted by focusing on territory games and practicing patience.
After injuries to Brian and Gordon, the team faced a six-day recovery period, emphasizing their preparation for future encounters.
The match against France was memorable, but it set the stage for a tough challenge ahead.

Nevertheless, Italy managed to get a try near the end of the first half, while the Scots played well in their territory game after suffering injuries to Brian and Gordon, but needing a recovery period.
The Scottish team is facing another tough challenge against Scotland on only six days' rest before the upcoming encounter with Italy.
Nevertheless, the focus will be on Scotland rather than Rome, as they will have to play a similar type of game against Italy.

However, Murphy is confident in the team's ability to handle such pressure and focuses on the upcoming match against Scotland.
